review_detail: Jim Jarmusch: His hair is a national treasure. And Paterson is the finest film in the indie writer-director's (he does the music too-and doesn't even take credit!) distinguished career.
Jarmusch, who made supernatural vampires seem human in Only Lovers Left Alive, now finds inspiration in the mundane.
[Paterson is] full of regard for the little things that warm its people's lives, and real respect for the ways they attempt to reach beyond their limitations, through creativity and humour.
The end result is Jarmusch's best (and most personal, seemingly) film to come around in quite some time...
Paterson is a quietly majestic paean to the life of the mind; to the perishability of everything.
Paterson left me with a feeling of hope.

Paterson's life sounds like it would be pretty dull to live through, let alone watch in a movie. But in writer-director Jim Jarmusch's hands, "Paterson" becomes a fascinating and enthralling film that finds magic in the mundane.
Paterson's bus is non-articulated, but he's as articulate as they come. ... Think Taxi Driver reimagined by Fred Rogers.

The different Patersons combine into a terrific take on love's abiding worth, the mechanics of creativity and the strength of community. The film has Jarmusch's trademark deadpan deliberation, but it's also possessed of a great and genuine heart.

Even those who have resisted Jarmusch's idiosyncratic style in the past may find themselves drawn to this charmingly offbeat ode to the lift that a touch of poetry can bring to an ostensibly mundane existence.
A filmmaker telling his story in pictures and the limitlessness of control he brings to his art. What more can one ask of cinema?
'Paterson' is a leisurely stroll through the lives of two creative individuals who support and love each other, and understand and embrace the other's foibles.
Jim Jarmusch's latest has moments of beauty that help compensate for a slightly static narrative.
Jim Jarmusch's Paterson is infused with the poetry of the quotidian, and defying the odds against this type of endeavor, Paterson is also one of the maverick filmmaker's most accessible films.

It's a pleasure to watch, so much so that I've viewed the film several times since receiving a screener copy in December. Paterson is different, distinct, and satisfying, one of the best films of 2016.
Driver cleverly doles out pieces of Paterson's being in such slow, steady increments that you're surprised by how deeply you've come to love this incredibly average guy.

Jarmusch takes us for a week in the life of his bus driver/poet (Driver), a working man with a kooky wife (Iranian actress Golshifteh Farahani), a spiteful dog, and pals and acquaintances that help make this film an easy, often charming watch.
Paterson is an exemplar... plumbing the passion for meter and the banality of the everyday while tapping into the rhythm and flow of the human condition.
For the second year in a row, my favorite film is a winning love story named for an urban area more or less in my backyard.
Adam Driver is the reason to see this special film from Jim Jarmusch.

Jarmusch is not trying to convey a message, but merely cultivating poetry with a unique texture. And while the pace may feel as slow as the bus's commute through Paterson, it is nevertheless a sublime slice of life in the city of bards.
Jim Jarmusch's latest film recalls some of his best work and, once again, the American indie maestro presents a unique and intricately crafted world.
An ode to Paterson and to poetry itself.
Paterson is a curiously charmin tale, dressed with some of the characteristic humor of it's author. [Full review in Spanish]
Paterson engages you from the start and leaves you with a smile. [Full review in Spanish]
The film is constructed with delicate symetries that feel mechanical yet uniquely beautiful. [Full review in Spanish]
A serene and adult reflection in zen mode about the beauty of being and exist in the world, day by day, moment by moment. [Full review in Spanish]

The film's poetry comes from Jarmusch's creativity and sensibility that exist in every detail and observation, from de couples' innocent kindness and the way he recorded that working neighborhood. [Full review in Spanish]

The film has incidents rather than plot: disruptions, minor mishaps, happy accidents. How Jarmusch takes this match-stick house of nothings and fills it with such calm and wisdom is a mystery with only one real answer: he's an artist.
Its restrained aesthetic and Driver's sublime, understated performance render it the director's most recognizably human and poignant film.
There's a quietly revelatory virtue to Jarmusch's film in its resistance to disturb its subject's life, to adhere to any typical conventions of film drama.
The great wonder of Paterson is that it makes a compelling tale of an apparently blissful life.
Pure poetry.
A mild-mannered, almost startlingly undramatic work that offers discreet pleasures to longtime fans of the New York indie-scene veteran, who can always be counted on to go his own way.
In "Paterson" the appeal of the Jarmusch vision shrinks down - in every way - to something relatively minimal.
Jim Jarmusch's sumptuous sonnet to poetry and ordinariness.
Jim Jarmusch's Paterson is a musing and life-affirming tract that both affirms and subverts the idea of mundanity in everyday life.
Paterson's writing may never earn such notice, but his perceptions on everyday existence are a quiet delight.
This is a sublime film about the democratic consolation of art, and of one another.
Like many of Jarmusch's best films, this keeps surprising us with its minimal, witty inflections, at once epic and small-scale.
[A] quietly seductive study of a guy named Paterson, a Paterson, New Jersey bus driver played by Adam Driver.
One of the director's finest to date, the film derives its unique power from the repetition of daily life, elevating the mundane to a kind of divinity.

Paterson, The Movie And The Melancholy Muse: The thwarted artist as whimsical working stiff in these economic hard times. And this typical economically depressed town, yet quirky and daffy, in the symbolically laden shadow of that bustling NYC metropolis.
Adam Driver makes the perfect Jim Jarmusch proxy in Paterson, the indie filmmaker's most accessible work.

Paterson is a movie so indebted to the necessity, futility, synthesis, isolation, validation, subversion, entertainment, and art of watching the world, that I feel reluctant to tell you anything but to give it a look.
The film concerns the humbler creative expressions of everyday life, where one creates art not for notoriety or superiority, but for the simple pleasure of making it.
It's a one-of-a-kind, strangely moving film, and as close as cinema gets to pure poetry.
Jim Jarmusch's Paterson, led by Adam Driver's skillfully restrained performance, is a brazing social commentary culminating in a harsh, yet beautiful truth.
A perfect little film that doesn't need to try too hard to win us over.
I love this movie.
Beneath this unassuming exterior is a beautiful tale of living a fulfilling existence.
Jim Jarmusch makes vibrant films/ Out of quiet distinctions/ A taste for perfect, ordinary things.
There's an austerity to [Paterson's] days and to his processes that Jarmusch sells very effectively. And so does Driver, with his off-kilter sincerity.

What a pleasure... that Driver not only delivers-giving a quiet, soulful, kindhearted performance that's my favorite thing he's done thus far-but that Jarmusch's film is as wise, winning, and surprisingly moving as it is
Paterson himself is deathly allergic to pretension, and the film inhabits his sensibility. It's A Portrait Of The Artist As A Working-Class Stiff, arguing for the mundane beauty of all our lives.
A lovely fable about the fragile, fruitful and occasionally fraught relationship between creativity and everyday life.
Driver, with his long, sloping brow and soulful lips, is both formidable and sympathetic, like an Easter Island statue that's a really good listener.
It's a thrilling rumination on the mimetic aspects of poetry, the inexplicable drive towards creativity and the search for meaning in the most simple acts of human expression.
For all its fine qualities, Paterson feels complacent and self-regarding. It's hard to listen to lectures in modesty from a film that's so busy admiring itself in the mirror.
[Jarmusch's] best in a decade.
True, some of Paterson's poems are just dull-dull. And the whimsy can be cloying. But the acting is fantastic.
A perfectly constructed, beautifully acted and utterly charming indie drama that will make you see the world around you in a different way. It is, in a word, unmissable.
Jarmusch is at his most refined here, as he carefully chronicles the humble exploits of one of life's observers.
Paterson offers a modest, slow-burning fanfare for the common man.
Slowly but surely, the gentleness of Jim Jarmusch's lovely new film steals up on you.
A quietly utopian film, and a balm to watch.
Jarmusch proves that it is possible to make a film in which the everyday can be turned into something mysterious and even transcendent. This a quiet film but ultimately a very rewarding one.
Everything is structured to evoke poetry through its measured pacing. The space left between events and interactions shows Jarmusch at his most poised.

Long-time fans won't be disappointed with Paterson; Jarmusch's trademark dry wit and attention to mood are all over it ... a beautifully modest movie and one of the best portraits of a working-class American you'll ever see. (Reviewer: Chris Neill)

Paterson, for me, succeeds in creating a tone that is very much its own, and by practising exceptional levels of dramatic restraint, delivers a ponderous, thoughtful experience, much like the ones in its protagonist's head.
A mesmeric treat of a film - one of Jarmusch's best.
Quiet, thoughtful and deeply human, this is one of Jarmusch's finest and features Adam Driver's best performance yet - although you do risk coming out with a new affection for modernist poetry.
Paterson is Jim Jarmusch's masterpiece.
Paterson is a warm and uncynical in its celebration of small-town life and dreams.
Director Jarmusch has a way of making the most mundane lives seem to matter. Greatly.
Paterson inhabits a wistful world in which language still has the power to cultivate art from the mundanity of everyday life.
A revealing character study, a reminder to recognise the small stuff that comprises much of our existence, and an appreciation of the ups and downs of living, all in one.
Jim Jarmusch's elegantly minimal and wryly comic study of Adam Driver's bus driver-poet celebrates and exemplifies a sturdy American vision of art as labor.
Nothing world-shaking happens in the film, but every second of its characters' routines feels rich with meaning.

"Paterson" is filled with moments and interactions that seem like they're headed toward drama but take a different route. And even though it's set in the present day, Paterson's quaint life evokes an earlier period, adding a thin layer of surrealism.
Jarmusch, that aging ambassador of cool, sincerely respects both the the ordinariness and the artistry of his blue-collar hero. One does not contradict the other. They are intimately related.
Keeping his distance from the granular details of psychic conflict, Jarmusch's domestic idyll veers distressingly close to some kind of working-class virtue fanfic.
Driver, fast becoming a thespian force, gives a considered and mature performance as the taciturn Paterson.

Jarmusch is justly revered as one of the fathers of modern independent American film, but his films have grown ever more wispy and self-congratulatory, Paterson, though artful in its way, is the most cloying of the lot.

Jarmusch expresses in a beautiful, deep and consistent manner his way of understanding the cinematographic narrative capturing the dead times, the repetitions and the pauses in the life of its characters. [Full review in Spanish]
A minimalist masterpiece where Jim Jarmusch shows a more romantic, poetic and even Zen side, and teaches us to appreciate the little things. [Full review in Spanish]
Poetry, cup cakes and an English bulldog are some of the unlikely ingredients of the film, whose existential themes weave an indelible, rich tapestry
The magnificent film's conceit is that ordinary folks are poets who might or might not know it.
An amazing little film that makes of simplicity its emblema so we can fall in love with its protagonist and the rest of the characters. [Full review in Spanish]

Adam Driver's wonderful performance and his sweet rapport with his on-screen wife, played with delicate compassion by Golshifteh Farahani, along with a hilariously expressive bulldog, are enough to save the film from its more obnoxious idiosyncrasies.
It glides along comfortably enough as a portrait of very ordinary lives somewhat lifted to the skies by both verse and cupcakes. Paterson isn't a bit patronising. It is just a rather sweet story.
A melancholic movie about melancholic characters leading melancholic lives. [Full review in Portuguese.]
Paterson quietly contemplates the creative process and the beauty of everyday things through the unlikely personage of a Star Wars villain. Who knew Driver could be so mesmerisingly motionless?
Once you realise that not a lot is going to happen, it's rather lovely to sit back and bask in its enormous, slightly melancholy charm.
What was charmingly loose-limbed in Jarmusch's earlier films now seems mannered and tired.
Jim Jarmusch has created a truly poetic film about a promising poet.
A meticulously composed movie, shot beautifully by Frederick Elmes; every frame is a beauty.
Mr. Jarmusch creates that rarest portrait of the artist: the one who's happy being hard at work.
"Paterson," like most films assured enough to make their own rules, is not just a refreshing change of pace but a revivifying one.
The movie is a charmer, as sweet as it is slow. But even some sympathetic viewers may find it nothing more than an almanac of neat stuff, less dramatized than merely cataloged.
Jarmusch salutes a life with a refreshing lack of drama.
This movie has almost no bite but plenty of moseying charm, and what it does get right is the idea of poets as perpetual magpies.
I've never seen a film that captures the inner world of an artist with such delicacy.
There's a hushed beauty to Paterson and Paterson that celebrates the way in which even the most ordinary, prosaic lives can be full of poetry.
I think it's admirable that the writer/director would like us to perhaps live a better life --- a quieter life, "Paterson" is too slow --- too simple --- for my enjoyment.
"Paterson" is decidedly not the tedious affair that was "The Limits of Control".
The film is as innocent as it is gentle, and viewing it is a truly sublime experience.
The film is about the act of creation and the art of observation, and it couldn't embody both more perfectly.
It's a whimsical story packed with wry humour, thoughtful emotion and some spicy details in both the people and places.
Paterson finds its true nirvana when it sits still and becomes Jarmuschian.
Paterson's a great character to have right now, and the movie about him - also called "Paterson," and set in the New Jersey city of Paterson - is great to watch now, too.
Visually creative drama with a sympathetic poet hero.
Here, Jarmusch says of artists (just as he suggested of vampires in Only Lovers Left Alive): they walk among us.
Driver's turn here is pure poetry.
A quiet miracle of a film, and a kind of sublime minimalist poem in itself.
A delightful, meandering meditation on finding art and beauty in the most ordinary of places.
The film's stubbornness to entirely reveal its intentions and its perpetual love for poetry is both fascinating and bizarre.
[Jarmusch] wants the audience to know that the world is poetry in motion, and we should save this dying art from extinction.
"Paterson" is simultaneously a paean to art and a tribute to working men-long-suffering men who toil in thankless isolation on repetitive jobs, carrying family responsibilities on their shoulders.
Driver's low-key charisma in the role rescues it from terminal dullness.
Here is an unexpected emotional powerhouse, a movie that defies the odds in serious ways, even with the imprimatur of writer-director Jim Jarmusch.
Gentle yet profound, Paterson serves as a moving reminder that beauty can be found in the everyday, that art can made everywhere, and that a poet lies in everyone.
Paterson, represents director Jim Jarmusch doing everything he does well to the best of his abilities.
A feature-length exploration of the linkages between routine, unexceptional daily life and the creation of art, and the kind of personality it takes to transform one into the other.

Adam Driver is disarmingly sincere as a simple man who finds a meaningful outlet through poetry--and it's the filmmaker's ability to find something pleasing, possibly beautiful, in the ordinary that makes the movie worthwhile
It's a turn of minor gestures that lacks the obvious Best Actor grandstanding to, say, win an Oscar, but rest assured Driver's performance is one of the most impressive given this year.
It's a distinct Jarmuschian effort, but I doubt few would want his work any other way.
A tribute to the life and times of a bus driver, poet, and master of everyday spirituality.

Paterson doesn't give answers, but it holds a lot of wisdom regardless. Jarmusch directs our attention through Paterson's and gives a glimpse of goodness that's in short supply, both onscreen and in the real world.
Jim Jarmusch and Paterson: here is the most beautiful match in the world.
The deliberately paced film rewards patience in its quiet observances of daily life and an almost poetic celebration of mundane details that shape our daily lives.
A beautiful little paean to the trivialities and triumphs of everyday life.

Adam Driver gives his loveliest, most lyrical performance in this Jim Jarmusch film-one of the year's best-that takes its good, sweet time working its way into your mind and heart. But when it does, you're a goner.
This is a movie about forgiveness - forgiving other people for what they do to us, forgiving ourselves for not always measuring up to some ideal.
Driver's Paterson doesn't blast his presence. Rather, he drifts into view, an unassuming shadow that only grows larger over the length of the film.
With each step, the film gains depth. Small variations in routine start to feel monumental, and the briefest encounter can seem like a sign of something great.
It's a perfect vehicle for Driver, who endearingly captures the hangdog humility of his character.
Driver is turning out to be one of the finest actors of the moment, an understated star with a great, non-movie-star face.
In Jim Jarmusch's new movie Paterson, there's no major action day to day, but magic is constantly bleeding in from around the edges.
Peripatetic bus driver personifies poetry in motion!
One of those rare, assured films that isn't particularly remarkable yet is enjoyable and charming in all the ways that matter most.
Like good poetry it moves at its own speed and every detail, every syllable, has profound impact.
Paterson is a procedural of the creative process. Paterson is also the best love story of the year, of two different varieties.

The quintessence of everything Jim Jarmusch has done before. Playful in approach, profound in meaning, it is a lyrical evocation of joy and sorrow as lived by a bus driver/poet during one eventful yet ordinary week in his life.
We come away from the film filled with the alertness and engagement Paterson and Laura bring to their days.
In a world beset by divisions and distractions, so much depends on Paterson, who looks at the world with clear eyes and finds beauty in the ordinary.
Viewers are treated to a portrait of romantic devotion, contentment and vocation all the more affecting for being so utterly, unapologetically heartfelt.
...exudes something that eludes so many of us: contentment.
Jarmusch has created a small miracle of a film, one that is both intellectually dazzling and emotionally provocative.

'Paterson' is a film extraordinary in its ordinariness, in its willingness to show us people like these, and to suggest that these will be their lives, and that there's nothing disappointing or shameful in that.
The film's leisurely pacing, which might take a moment to adjust to, mirrors the bus driver's own unhurried rhythm, allowing the audience to experience the world from his very particular perspective.
[Jarmusch's] minimalist style has kept evolving over the years, and on the evidence seen (and felt here), he is nearing a new career peak that few of his peers will ever reach.
... a wry meditation on the nature of creativity ... Adam Driver is wonderful as the would-be poet searching for inspiration in all the wrong places ... Jarmusch's sweetest, most accessible film
It's absolutely worth hunting down for any passionate cinephile.
Here's a sweet and lovely film, from director Jim Jarmusch, featuring a pair of breakout performances and a lived-in sense of place for Paterson, NJ. (Splice Today)
Still, Paterson's single week offers a persuasive manifesto for a contemplative, non-incident-based form of poetic cinema, and for the virtues of poetic sensibility.

As a portrait of a relationship of would-be famous artists-he who follows a strict routine and she who changes her artistic pursuit on a whim-Jarmusch does not take a stance that one is better, just that simply doing is the best.
Paterson is a lovely film about a man of simple wants and needs...
I'd rank Paterson among [Jarmusch's] very best films. It's a treasure, and the best American film of 2016.

Poetry is about taking the realities of your life and the complexities of your mind and heart and transforming them into something beautiful and pure, and that's exactly what Jarmusch does with Paterson. It's lovely stuff.
Jarmusch is a next-level storyteller with an amazing ability to deliver a scene that works on face value and as a metaphor
It's an unlikely story of the art of the everyday: warm, funny and possessing a lolling rhythm and a great lead performance by Adam Driver.
Poetry shows us how just a few words can be full of meaning. "Paterson," a tone poem of a film, goes about its business the same way, with simple gestures that contain a lot and work on many levels.
...about dreamers, opposites and the deep happiness found in an optimistic view of life.
If it sounds like not much happens in this film, well, have you ever seen a Jim Jarmusch movie?
I think Jarmusch has actually remade "Groundhog Day" as a work of spiritual ecstasy. I also think Paterson the man may be a Zen Ralph Kramden.
An aged hipster's take on what a young working class poet might be like...static. Humorless.
Paterson is a keen observer of the meaning the mundane. As is Jarmusch's poetic film.
Or would you rather be a fish?

The story takes place over the space of one week. Minor triumphs and tragedies that seem exaggerated in importance amid the sameness. There is also some drama in the story because of the crazy things that love does to a person's mind.
Jarmusch was always funny, but there's warmth now, too.
Jarmusch's setting, in its heightened sense of the mundane, reminds us unmistakably of the filmmaker's vision of Cleveland, Ohio, in his 1984 breakthrough Stranger Than Paradise.
Patient, watchful and quietly transcendent.
A certain type of viewer (particularly white dudes with literary aspirations) will want to jump right into the film and live there...
Driver's performance as an uncertain man getting through the day-to-day prosaic, quietly buoyed by passion and artistic commitment, is exquisite.

Paterson is easily one of Jarmusch's most accomplished films. He portrays the life of the mind and the workings of the creative soul as a kind of secret love affair, a deep, hidden well inside the most ordinary, mundane existence.
